Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place  Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second delves into "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force  we're running out of time, we've saved time, and we're just in time. He aims to demonstrate that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. This book is the first reading to have captivated me thus far.

Fall 1974  I was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I'm not a math person, nor am I now. I hate math; I'm math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and, just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding, the doorbell rang again. Just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.

As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not affected). They basically fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), i.e. the boss fights are awesome, weapons feel very nice, enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a novice with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really well-balanced, and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. There are lots of cool, unique weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and Stan Bush's stuff.

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts - ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and so on. I felt much more attached to this character as well. While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20 hours. I would have really liked a save option to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. The aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat 'em up is great. I've been playing it as often as I can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

This is an absolute great strategy game! Having played every single other war game (European Escalation and Albion), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there are a plethora of them. Graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no I'm not kidding. However, if you think this game is 'easy', or if you're new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Don't get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for Energon games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster, which adds depth to the gameplay.

The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution fell short for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still just didn't find the gameplay itself enjoyable. It also lacks a pause button, which seems like a critical oversight, given that many sequences in the game are timed. I also feel like this game is a lot more cutscene than it is game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game was an incredible experience. I was hooked from the story to the graphics. The story wasn't just a story, but it felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story that my character was telling. Gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game. My gut churned the whole time, but I kept going for Uncle Fred. If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this, you made an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In this game, you're set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that it took a new approach to the game and added new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, what I didn't enjoy was that the game could be overwhelming at times. I think what could be improved is incorporating some new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game! In my top 5 zombie games ever played. After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, where you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, and so on. I find the zombies to feel very natural to be well-animated for a free-to-play game. I would recommend getting one or two friends to play with, as the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game breakers. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, and creates unbearable lag. I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game. Everything, like the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game, is a mess. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my OC. I set my GPU back to stock and sure enough, and it didn't make a difference.

Last night, I finished this game. The story may not be particularly deep or captivating, but the storytelling shines. The atmosphere is rich and the many collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a little disappointing that there were so few boss battles in the game. However, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge, but it's slightly on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add for nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places makes for a sense of progression.

To the moon is no mere game; nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's the walking dead is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for to the moon! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story, and the references to the doctor are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game, with a great storyline. After a calamity, you start rebuilding on the bastion. The game offers a lot of choice, from choosing what to build to give you an advantage, to selecting weapons and power-ups for those weapons, as well as drinks to use for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, making the game visually stunning at times. The narration is also player-driven, with the story adapting to the player's actions. If you pick up a weapon, the narration will adapt to your new choice, commenting on your decision to switch to another in the armoury.

I originally purchased this game during its early development, when the primary currency was spacebux, and the tech tree was nonexistent. At this stage, the game was enjoyable. All the guns at this point were equally overpowered, eliminating any concerns about balance; everyone could kill anyone at any moment. The game also provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You might expect that for a game with an immense arsenal of guns, they would offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring additional payment. In reality, I had approximately three pages' worth of guns and was planning new ideas for more, as I found it entertaining.

This game was a delightful discovery. One often sees glowing reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews accurately capture the fun of this charming little game. It's an unusual blend between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with flair. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface are quaintly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I recently started playing and have become deeply engrossed in the game, often losing track of time. It's been a while since a game has had such a profound impact on me. The music perfectly sets the mood, sound effects are spot on, and controls are seamless. I eagerly anticipate each combat, and they've executed combat exceptionally well. Initially, I had some reservations about the naval combat system, but it's surprisingly enjoyable to unleash havoc on multiple fleets at once. The only way to lose is to fail to retreat. If combat appears overwhelming, simply retreat, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks to the developers for an incredible experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. The game serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch.

Where do I start on this stunning game? It's story is absolutely charming, with so much detail put into it, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, and secrets. The character design is on point, with various characters having distinct personalities and secrets to them. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in RPGs. With lots of inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell it's going to be good. It has one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a long time.

I'm recommending this game solely because it's free and might be a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game didn't do much for me. Half the story relies on shock value. I wasn't shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction out of me. The other half of the game tries to paint a picture of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucinations, depression, and a few other things. In theory, it's a cool idea. Unfortunately, the game took me 10 minutes to complete, and that's with reading and taking in every little bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept, then gets out. It's an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story-heavy, it gave birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and love to come back and see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. The gameplay is quite simple  you use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to put on.

If you can overlook the minor bugs, I can definitely recommend this game. The one minor bug and the other quite annoying bug have been resolved, resulting in a significant increase in my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. I'll include my specs  i5 6600k, Radeon RX 480, Z170 Pro Gaming, 16GB DDR4 RAM, and a total cost of around 650. While this rig is quite new, it's definitely within the medium price range. I can genuinely say that I'm almost constantly getting 60+ FPS on high settings with vsync enabled, which is impressive considering 90% of the comments say they're running an overkill setup and getting 20 FPS.

Remember the age of mythology? Indeed, it's been a while since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favorite RTS game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hits the spot. I'm not (read  try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, I do like the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civilization V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this  if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have come out, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and it shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, of which I am still trying to learn; however, this breadth of strategy allows you a myriad of ways to reach goals and take advantage of certain situations.

Warframe is a fun game for the initial hours of play. After those hours, you'll begin to see that the game's content is repetitive, with limited variety in combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is the developers' dedication to regular updates, which often include significant changes to the game's systems, new Warframes, and other features. It's a good game for casual play. While it may not hold your attention for an extended period, it's worth trying out. The upside is that the game is free, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, it's worth a try.

This game is extremely underwhelming. I purchased this game believing it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a well-known and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short of my expectations. In this game, you progress by absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb bigger things. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, and the levels lack inventiveness, leaving what's in it feeling like a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that makes you question whether being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things as someone very interested in politics. I was very interested in this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side  Republican or Democrat, there is no independent, or third party. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I continued on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign.

Fallout 3's story was better. Settlers get in the way of the story to the point you'll hate babysitting them instead of playing the story. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs galore. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point and had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor; it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game, and power cores are everywhere in trader shops. The value of power armor is diminished greatly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, everything about this game is mediocre except it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. Very stable compared to Fallout 3. While it's not as bad as some make it out to be, it's not better than Fallout 3. This title was overhyped for how bad it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review)  8.6 hours to get to the end, 10 collectibles found out of 25, zero achievements out of 15. What I liked  visuals up until the last level (Ice Caves), story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game. What I disliked  visuals in the last level are uninteresting, gameplay in the last level gets much harder, making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right. Achievements are too hard. There are 13 (out of 15) that only less than 2.1% of players achieved.

Pros  +graphic - Cons  -bugs, especially in the environment, where you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy. -game is handholding/babysitting you -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are when you're spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy, which is frustrating. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that I couldn't care less about; I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off. Even then, I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move on to the next game in my library.

Review for November 29, 2015  Do not buy this game, servers offline. You can't play. No comprare este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the song of the Steve Miller Band...  go on, take the money and run! The game is awesome, with 73 minutes of playtime. Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking can be unfair, but hey, it's still a fun game!

It's not hard for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I'm more interested in playing room-sized games with controllers. While the game's scale is initially awe-inspiring, it also hindered my enjoyment due to the steep learning curve and the time it took to do anything interesting. Perhaps if I were more patient, it would be more compelling. However, I don't have the time and there are other VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time, you will have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I didn't purchase EU when it first came out and I got it on sale, which included EU, so I never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however, it was unforgiving in the early stages, but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game plays pretty well for me on medium, and I'm running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. At first, the game set it to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. But when I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they're coming from some really entitled people.

RPG leveling with a wide variety of ship types, physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles, and easy-to-learn resource management, this game is a blast. However, it has some drawbacks, such as grind-intensive gameplay, subpar AI teammates, and a limited variety of equipment types and leveling skills. Despite these drawbacks, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. The game starts off quickly and maintains its pace. Even with a limited selection of equipment, it feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. To maximize the game's potential, mods are the way to go. The fight for universe is easily the star, but a big fight for beef is also very good.

World leaders are gathering in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving for the five-day event. The agenda includes discussions on China's economic power, Iraq's future after Sunday's elections, and other pressing global issues. Notable attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among over 20 government leaders and heads of state. In a departure from previous years, protests against the WEForum are expected to be subdued, as anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEForum's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline Looms for Fiat-GM Deal: Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. This deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose European operations are struggling, no longer wants to own Fiat's unprofitable unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares tumbling 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% gain on Monday on hopes of a resolution. GM is reportedly offering around $2bn (1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal was the result of a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes the Iraq war, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has spoken out against the war, denouncing it as a "terrible" waste of money. He will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to express his concerns about the war, stating that "billions" have been spent on war instead of being used to alleviate poverty, malnutrition, and disease. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out against the war, urging for a change in direction. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he emphasized that 2005 should be a year for campaigning to "make history and make poverty history".

British stars dashed hopes of winning major Oscars were crushed as UK stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, said it was 'totally overwhelming' to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant, working her way up the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were typically held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression and fast web access, encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. According to a report by UK think-tank Demos, a quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites. Having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and this number is growing fast. The report found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. The report argues that broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is facing a US court date on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The company is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yugasnkneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all legal means.

Voters flock to the blog awards site, where voting is currently underway for the annual bloggies, recognizing the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, and traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to the overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with the word "blog" being named the top US dictionary's word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs, with more than 12,000 added daily. According to Pew Internet and American Life research, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

China's 'Defies Beijing' dam firm, the Three Gorges Project Corp, is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, according to the Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, the Beijing News said. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects halted due to lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News said the company may choose to pay a fine instead.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales "must learn health lessons" from England, says the new Health Minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role. He acknowledged "big challenges" but emphasized that the "essentials" were in place to tackle waiting lists. Despite this, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats called for policy changes. Meanwhile, Jane Hutt, his predecessor, defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprised "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, and Assembly Member for Aberavon, said NHS staff sought a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." During his predecessor's five-and-a-half-year tenure as the Assembly's first Health Minister, one of the biggest issues was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Manchester United boss. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed, which no other player has got.

Singer George Michael's documentary film will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival, offering a candid look at the life of the chart-topping singer. The film, running from February 10-20, features Michael discussing his career and personal life, from his early days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will introduce the screening on February 16, accompanied by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute film explores Michael's early days in Wham! as well as his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance on the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two in Billboard's Pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales will be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations which play chart music.

The self-proclaimed spam king, Scott Richter, is seeking bankruptcy protection for his company, Optinrealbig.com, which has been fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. Optinrealbig was listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus and was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini had felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems." Arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added  "Santini has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland maintained their six-nation grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but they struggled to turn pressure into points.

Economy will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown said, after Cabinet members held their last meeting at No 10 Downing Street before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that Labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle 'yob culture' and the Lib Dems gave more details about their proposals to replace Council Tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run in Sheffield, Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Mark Carroll confirmed in mid-week that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with Cragg occupying top spot.

Warning  Avoid a scam website claiming to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site may appear legitimate due to its use of an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, it has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. This is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email that is currently circulating. The subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterizes many other phishing attempts.

Iraq is inviting phone licence bids, seeking to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The Ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% to about 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the Ministry's website on February 9. Additionally, a road-show is planned for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women turn to the internet to secure older people and women, who are increasingly taking charge of protecting their home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect PCs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for internet security firm, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has increased by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women, 53%, were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio on an Apple iPod or other digital music players, which can hold up to 10,000 songs, a considerable amount of space to fill. But more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you do not need an iPod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

Andrea Levy's novel "Small Island" has won the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty". Geraldine McCaughren has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for "Not the End of the World". All the category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries with it a 25,000 prize. A panel of judges including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant and writer Joanne Harris will meet up on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale  Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, 4.8bn) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction, has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Jamieson, Scotland's justice minister, has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their work in tackling the problem. The minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive.

Uk debut for Kevin Spacey's movie, Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife - real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Friday) Headingley, 25 February 2000 GMT, the Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds  Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements  Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMullin, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the UK, Germany, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It shows that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future is definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

Jrgen Melzer delivered a stunning upset, defeating second-seeded Andre Agassi 6-3, 6-1 in the quarterfinals of the SAP Open. Agassi was frequently caught off guard by Melzer's clever drop shots in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to defeat Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Unseeded Cyril Saulnier surprised fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer said. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I aimed to disrupt his rhythm, as he tends to make opponents run tirelessly across the court."

Mps to lords' replacement plan a group of mps has tried to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. Mps and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Disappointed Scott Allan is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jos M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP) for allegedly programming its printer ink cartridges to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs to be refilled, even when it is not empty. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. The ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims that the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin radio offers 3G broadcast UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, which enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said, "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said, "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on the Isle of Wight will appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The event, which takes place from June 10-12, has already confirmed headliners, including Roxy Music, along with Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzarek, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson. The band members are also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Bryan Ferry, Andy Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Phil Manzarek joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for the aid match, Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

Spirit awards hail the comedy Sideways as it has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named best film, with Alexander Payne winning best director and best screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars.

Prince crowned "top music earner" prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5 million from concerts, album and publishing sales with his musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9 million while embarking on her global re-invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9 million last year. Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness, the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3 million in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album Musicology.

U2 have been honored at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by a boy band. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ music awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. U2 was named best new international artist, and took the best international song title for this love. More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  "I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the Cte d'Azur I feel at home."

Wal-Mart fights back at accusers with two big US names, launching advertising campaigns to set the record straight about their products and corporate behavior. The world's biggest retailer Wal-Mart took out more than 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers. The group is trying to deflect criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, drug group Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-Mart kicked off the battle with adverts in newspapers like the Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company President Lee Scott saying it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about Wal-Mart, but facts are facts.

Tories outlining policing plans for local communities would ask residents to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He stated that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticised "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential that operational independence was retained. Jan Berry said  "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

At a glance  Tory health checks the UK's opposition's plans to introduce health checks for immigrants, if they win the general election. A guide to the plan  people coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of TB, they would have to have a chest X-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical check. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, knocking US act Scissor Sisters off the number one spot. The trio's album follows the success of single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly takes the number one single spot with Over and Over, featuring Tim McGraw. The top ten is dominated by Girls Aloud, Akon, Kaiser Chiefs, Futureheads, and Usher, while Elvis Presley's latest re-release, 'Marie's the Name', debuts at number three.

Davies prefers Gloucester's future over Wales' hooker Mefin Davies, who is likely to remain with the English side despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he prefers to stay where he is. As one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, Davies is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, he has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies without a professional contract, forcing him to take a semi-professional deal with Neath RFC. Although he gained match experience with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, Davies admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with his treatment.

Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated 512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a 1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is set to make history by fielding four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, in the UEFA Cup. The club, the first Arab side to participate in European competition, will face English Premier League team Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who impressed at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in helping Bnei Sakhnin defeat Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. The 28-year-old goalkeeper recently joined the club after a brief stint with South African side Hellas. Last season, Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin won the Israeli Cup and are based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club is known for its strong ethnic diversity and promotes peace and co-operation within Israel.

A new report suggests that cutting drink-drive limits could save more lives than previously thought. According to a University College London study, reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives annually. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines, but not the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also suggests that cutting the limit would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003, saving the country 119 million annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested a similar move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 m diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512x512 m. The proposed system measures pulse width, the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, instead of sensing voltage drops caused by radiation. This eliminates the need for power-hungry analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the creation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This capability has inspired ideas for using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the linear interaction between motion and light or electricity prevents access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested the possibility of overcoming this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make informed decisions. However, the evaluations can be compromised by professional spammers who have developed increasingly sophisticated and powerful spamming strategies to evade detection. These strategies are difficult to capture as they can quickly adapt to new detectors and target various products. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which is not aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of this game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share the same structural form, which partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussian distributions to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian distribution to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup g of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface x_m in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial w_m. The first, Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHKS) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface x_mt inside it by some dual group g^t. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this study, a generalization of the human gait was derived from existing models in the literature, including models by Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a metabolic energy minimization strategy is combined in a racing process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, attempting to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for various speed regimes, suggest that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a crucial quantity in quantifying this dynamic process. An experimental procedure was conducted in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Manuel Beltrn University in Bogot, Colombia.

We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. The method is based on a time regularization technique, which maintains the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. A high-order mvs scheme enables integration with large time steps, even in regions far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm can resolve almost exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems, such as the solar system. We showcase the long-term behavior of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50,000 years. Our algorithm is compared to hybrid methods, including Mercury, and shows that for an equivalent cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size makes it challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For n-partite GHZ-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/3 white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, providing a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Our results suggest that current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short-term interactions or long-term structural connections. In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility, while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for transducing beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs, enabling optomechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences split into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra mo and mu, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of o(n) and u(n).

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this paper, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, have been shown to be amongst the most challenging audio files to process. Building speech processing models capable of handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by children, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. Our diverse child-centered corpora, comprising a total of 260 hours of recordings, covers 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, unknown, population structure allows framing the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. Nonparametric modal clustering draws a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, along with a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, to identify the final partition. We address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher-dimensional operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analysis with a causal objective. The introduction of the term 'data science' provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. We organize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science, and we believe that this lack of clarity has led to a misinterpretation of the term 'data science'.

The weak gravity conjecture demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore suggests that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it remains unclear what goes wrong if this doesn't happen. This note shows that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a non-perturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einstein's gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity vc. We measure vc as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for investigating the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models with intuitive appeal for modeling various applications, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering. Despite their widespread use in modeling, the frequent lack of analytic solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from the data, particularly when the model has numerous variables and parameters. This paper presents a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver. It enables fast estimation by avoiding the computation of the entire numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. The chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, significantly influences the transport characteristics of the junction. Notably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated as an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. It provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of the method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, especially if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of approximately 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, rooted in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrme charge for any smooth configuration. Notably, singular configurations emerge, which can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. The vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields on the quantum Hall droplet forming the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current accurately represents the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified framework for the two types of baryons, enabling a natural transformation between them. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be seen as a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an innovative way to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device.
